overview: Married Couple’s Allowance (MCA) reduces your tax bill - what you'll get, eligibility and applying
title: Married Couple's Allowance

table.body:
If you're a taxpayer, Married Couple's Allowance (MCA) reduces your tax bill.

Who can claim MCA - and the amount - depends on:

- the date you married - or entered into a civil partnership
- the age of the older partner - one of you must be **born before 6 April 1935**
- your income

##If you married before 5 December 2005
The husband gets the MCA - the amount depends on their income and the age of the older partner.

##If you married on or after 5 December 2005 or are in a civil partnership
The person with the higher income can claim MCA - the amount depends on the age of the older partner and the income of the partner with the higher income.

*[MCA]: Married Couple's Allowance
table.title: Overview

table.body:
For 2011/12, the minimum amount of MCA is £2,800 and the maximum amount is £7,295.

You get 10% of the allowance amount - so your tax bill could be reduced by at least £280 and up to £729.50.

##How MCA is worked out
To work out MCA you need to know your income and what your [Personal Allowance](/income-tax-rates "Income Tax Personal Allowance") is - this is the amount of income you're allowed before you have to pay Income Tax.

- the basic Personal Allowance for 2011/12 is £7,475
- the age-related Personal Allowance for someone aged 75 and over is £10,090
- for [Income Tax](/income-tax "Income Tax") purposes, your income includes pensions (State, company and personal), rental income and interest on savings or shares before tax has been taken off

##Income limit
Based on a full year's eligibility, you get the maximum amount if your income isn't more than £24,000 - the 'income limit'.

If your income is over £24,000 (before any allowances) your MCA is reduced in the same way that your age-related [Personal Allowance](/income-tax-rates "Income Tax Personal Allowance") can be reduced.

The reduction is worked out like this:

- half your income that's over the limit for the age-related Personal Allowance is deducted until the basic Personal Allowance is reached
- anything that's left is taken off the MCA until the minimum amount is reached

If your income doesn't reduce the age-related Personal Allowance to the basic level, your MCA isn't reduced.

$E
**Example**  
You're 77 and have an income (before allowances) of £29,600    
The income limit is subtracted from your income (£29,600 - £24,000)  
This shows you're £5,600 over the limit - half of this (£2,800) is taken off your MCA  

This £2,800 is taken off your MCA as follows:  
  
Your age-related Personal Allowance is reduced to the basic Personal Allowance level (£10,090 - £7,475 = £2,615)    
Half of the amount you're over the income limit (£2,800) is subtracted by £2,615 = £185    
This is subtracted from the MCA amount (£7,295 - £185) leaving £7,110    
You MCA is 10% of this = £711.00    

Your tax bill is reduced by this amount.    

$E








*[MCA]: Married Couple's Allowance
table.title: What you'll get

table.body:
You can claim Married Couple's Allowance (MCA) if:

- you're married or in a civil partnership 
- you're a taxpayer
- you or your spouse or civil partner were **born before 6 April 1935**

##The date you marry or enter into a civil partnership
You get MCA for each tax year that you're living together.

If you marry (or enter into a civil partnership) during the tax year (eg halfway through), your allowance will be based on the month it takes place.

$E
**Example**   
If you get married on 24 March, you would only get a twelfth, or 1 month's worth, of the allowance for that tax year, which begins 6 April.
$E

If one of you dies, or if you divorce or separate, the MCA continues until the end of that tax year.

*[MCA]: Married Couple's Allowance
table.title: Eligibility

table.body:
Contact HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC) to claim.

You must give details of your:

- marriage or civil partnership ceremony
- spouse or civil partner - including date of birth

table.title: How to claim

table.body:
##Transfer your MCA after the end of the tax year
If your spouse or civil partner pays tax, you can transfer any unused allowance to them if:

- you don’t pay tax
- your tax bill isn't high enough

Use the form below or contact [HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC)](married-couples-allowance#how-to-claim "Contact HM Revenue & Customs") who can post you a copy. 

$D
[Download form 575 'Notice of transfer of surplus Income Tax allowances' - (PDF, 64K)](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/forms/575-t-man.pdf "Form 575 - Notice of transfer of surplus Income Tax allowances"){:rel="external"} 
$D

##Share or transfer your MCA before the start of the tax year
You and your spouse (or civil partner) can also:

- share the minimum MCA
- transfer the whole of the minimum MCA from one to the other

Complete the form below before the start of the tax year - you can also contact [HMRC](married-couples-allowance#how-to-claim "Contact HM Revenue & Customs") to get a copy in the post.

$D
[Download form 18 'Transferring the Married Couple’s Allowance' - (PDF, 88K)](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/forms/18.pdf "form 18 - Transferring the Married Couple’s Allowance"){:rel="external"}
$D

##Tax allowances and giving to charity

If you pay tax and give money to a UK charity using Gift Aid, let [HMRC](married-couples-allowance#how-to-claim "HM Revenue & Customs") know. It reduces your income when they calculate your age-related allowances.



*[MCA]: Married Couple's Allowance
*[HMRC]: HM Revenue & Customs
